importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication reflects the most up-to-date interim findings regarding the funicular crash in Lisbon, indicating ongoing investigation and public concern about safety standards in public transportation systems.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The crash occurred in September 2025, and the interim report was released in October 2025, highlighting a critical safety failure that occurred recently and is still under review.

keyTakeAways: A steel cable in the Glória funicular in Lisbon failed to meet operational specifications and was not certified for carrying passengers.

The cable snapped shortly after the funicular cars began their journey on Calçada da Glória, causing one car to derail and crash into a building, killing at least 16 people and injuring several others.
Eyewitnesses described the crash as chaotic and sudden, with one man named Bruno reporting that the car appeared 'completely out of control' and that a loud bang and brown smoke were observed.
The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and braking systems.
Maintenance tasks were falsely marked as completed, and the maintenance plan was recorded as 'compliant and accepted' by the operator, despite not being properly executed.
The cable did not meet the specifications set by CARRIS, the operator of the funicular.
A final report on the crash is expected to be released next year, and the interim findings are described as preliminary and not conclusive.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A preliminary investigation by Portugal's GPIAAF into a deadly September 2025 funicular crash in Lisbon found that a steel cable in the Glória funicular failed to meet the operator CARRIS's specifications and was not certified for passenger use. The cable snapped shortly after the cars began their journey on Calçada da Glória, causing one car to derail and crash into a building, killing at least 16 people and injuring several others. Eyewitnesses described the event as sudden and chaotic. The investigation also revealed serious maintenance failures, including false completion records and a flawed maintenance plan that was improperly accepted by the operator. While the interim findings are not conclusive, they indicate systemic failures in safety protocols, raising urgent concerns about public transport safety standards in Portugal and globally.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
